Authors:
Samuli Lehtonen, Daniele Silvestro, Dirk Nikolaus Karger,
Christopher Scotese, Hanna Tuomisto, Michael Kessler, Carlos Pena,
Niklas Wahlberg, Alexandre Antonelli
Title:
Environmentally driven extinction and opportunistic
origination explain fern diversification patterns
Abstract:
Combining palaeontological and neontological data o ers a
unique opportunity to investigate the relative roles of biotic and
abiotic controls of species diversi cation, and the importance of
origination versus extinction in driving evolutionary dynamics. Ferns
comprise a major terrestrial plant radiation with an extensive
evolutionary history providing a wealth of modern and fossil data for
modelling environmental drivers of diversi cation. Here we develop a
novel Bayesian model to simultaneously estimate correlations between
diversi cation dynamics and multiple environmental trajectories. We
estimate the impact of di erent factors on fern diversi cation over the
past 400 million years by analysing a comprehensive dataset of fossil
occurrences and complement these ndings by analysing a large molecular
phylogeny. We show that origination and extinction rates are governed by
fundamentally di erent processes: originations depend on within-group
diversity but are largely una ected by environmental changes, whereas
extinctions are strongly a ected by external factors such as climate and
geology. Our results indicate that the prime driver of fern diversity
dynamics is environmentally driven extinction, with origination being an
opportunistic response to diminishing ecospace occupancy.
